examples: He glanced at the letter and then tossed it into the bin.
The bull tossed him up into the air.

body_content.explanation: When you toss food you shake or mix small pieces of it together with a sauce or dressing:
examples: Serve French beans tossed in a little garlic butter.

body_content.explanation: to quickly and suddenly lift the pan in which a pancake (= a thin, flat, round cake) is cooking so that the pancake goes up into the air and turns over before falling back into the pan:
examples: Ben came second in the competition after tossing a pancake 21 times.

body_content.explanation: If you toss your hair or a part of your body you move it up and back suddenly:
examples: She tossed her head in annoyance.

body_content.explanation: to move about from side to side or turn a lot in bed, especially because you cannot sleep:
examples: I was tossing and turning all night.

body_content.explanation: to throw a coin up into the air and guess which side will land facing up, as a way of making a decision:
examples: Let's toss (a coin) to see who'll go first.
"I'll toss you for it - heads or tails?"

body_content.explanation: to order a sports player or manager to leave a game because they have broken a rule:
examples: I got tossed after I argued with the officials.
The umpire tossed our pitcher for deliberately throwing at a batter.
"I don't care," she replied with a toss of her head.

body_content.explanation: an act of throwing a coin in the air and guessing which side will land facing upward as a way of deciding something:
to guess correctly/wrongly which side of a coin will be facing up when it lands on the ground after being thrown:
examples: The team that wins the toss gets to start the game.

body_content.explanation: an act of throwing something in a careless or relaxed way
